title: Drawing, Plate Design:  Les Liqueurs [Liquor], for the Services des Objets des Dessert [Service on the Theme of Desserts], 1819–20
title_raw: Plate Design:  Les Liqueurs [Liquor], for the Services des Objets des Dessert [Service on the Theme of Desserts]
medium: Pen and brown ink, brown wash on cream laid paper, circular border in pen and brown ink
inscribed: Inscribed in pen and brown ink,  upper center:  Les liqueurs [Liquors]; across upper fourth of sheet:  Un gros amateur de liqueurs enverse a un petit/garçon; [words crossed out over which is written] sa petite soeur lui fait [unreadable]/que il en boit il deviendra comme le personnage d'un tableau/flamand, qu'elle lui montre.  Sur le devant, caisse/de bouteiller de toutes les sortes/au fond laboratoire de distilation [A big connoisseur of liquors, he pours for a little/boy; the small sister makes him drink it and in so doing he will become like the image in the Flemish painting/that she shows him.  In the foreground, a case/of bottles of all kinds./In the rear the distillation laborabory]; in graphite, center left margin:  pour le punch [for punch]; verso, in pen and brown ink, lower left:..1820
provenance:
Collection H.N.
Spencer Samuels, New York
dimensions: 18.2 x 15.2 cm (7 3/16 x 6 in. ), at widest point
description: Scene in a liquor shop.  People seated at a table, right middleground, being served by a waiter who holds a tray with decanters and glasses of liquor.  On the wall, center middleground, a Flemish tavern [?] interior depicting a waitress with a drunk man on the floor.  A case of liquor bottles is on the floor, left foreground.  The distillation process takes place in a rear room, left background.  In left margin center, a sketch of the waiter's arm holding the serving tray; lower left margin, a rough sketch of woman's head and right arm.

tombstone.epitaph:
Drawing, Plate Design:  Les Liqueurs [Liquor], for the Services des Objets des Dessert [Service on the Theme of Desserts], 1819–20. Pen and brown ink, brown wash on cream laid paper, circular border in pen and brown ink. 
1989-13-25
